title: Mild to Moderate Hypercalcaemia

notes: Risk of progression to severe hypercalcemia if untreated

signs: Normal neurological exam unless higher levels
diagnosis: Identify cause (e.g., malignancy, primary hyperparathyroidism, thiazide use)
management_non_emergency: Encourage oral hydration
Treat underlying cause (e.g., stop thiazides, treat malignancy)
Consider IV 0.9% saline if oral intake inadequate
Bisphosphonates (e.g., zoledronic acid) if persistent or symptomatic hypercalcemia
Monitor calcium levels regularly
prognosis_disposition: Good with early hydration and treatment
Risk of renal impairment or arrhythmias if untreated

title: Severe Hypercalcemia

notes: Risk of arrhythmias, coma, and renal failure

investigations: Serum total and ionized calcium levels (>3.5 mmol/L total calcium)
Consider PTH, vitamin D, and malignancy screen (if underlying cause unknown)
diagnosis: Confirmed hypercalcemia with compatible clinical symptoms
management_emergency: IV 0.9% saline for aggressive rehydration (4-6L/day)
IV bisphosphonates (e.g., zoledronic acid 4 mg IV over 15 min) once adequately hydrated
Consider calcitonin for rapid temporary lowering of calcium
Dialysis if refractory or renal failure present
prognosis_disposition: Good if treated early with fluids and bisphosphonates
Poor prognosis if underlying malignancy is the cause

title: Mild to Moderate Hyperkalaemia

notes: Often asymptomatic but risk of progression to severe hyperkalemia

symptoms: May have muscle weakness or fatigue
signs: If mnore severe Reduced reflexes, muscle weakness
investigations: ECG (may be normal or minor peaked T waves)
management_non_emergency: Stop potassium-retaining drugs (e.g., ACE inhibitors, ARBs, spironolactone)
Oral potassium binders if needed (e.g., sodium polystyrene sulfonate)
Increase potassium excretion: consider loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide)
Dietary potassium restriction
Repeat potassium in 6-24 hours depending on clinical status
red_flags: ECG changes (peaked T waves, widened QRS)
prognosis_disposition: Good with medication review, dietary advice, and monitoring
Risk of severe hyperkalemia if untreated

title: Severe Hyperkalemia
investigations: ECG (Tall peaked T waves, widened QRS, flattened P waves, sine wave pattern)
diagnosis: Hyperkalemia confirmed by serum potassium >6.5 mmol/L
management_emergency: Immediate IV calcium gluconate 10 mL 10% over 5-10 min (cardiac membrane stabilization)
Insulin + dextrose infusion (e.g., 10 units actrapid in 50 mL of 50% dextrose IV over 15-30 min) to shift K+ intracellularly
Nebulized salbutamol (10-20 mg) to drive K+ into cells
Sodium bicarbonate IV if acidosis present
Stop potassium-sparing drugs (e.g., ACE inhibitors)
Treat underlying cause
Consider dialysis if refractory or severe renal failure
prognosis_disposition: Good with prompt recognition and aggressive treatment
Mortality high if delayed treatment or in cardiac arrest

title: Mild to Moderate Hypernatraemia

notes: Risk of progression to severe hypernatremia if untreated

diagnosis: Confirmed serum sodium between 145 and 159 mmol/L
management_non_emergency: Identify and correct underlying cause (dehydration, diabetes insipidus, diuretics)
Encourage oral fluid intake (preferably hypotonic fluids like water)
In patients unable to drink: IV 5% dextrose or 0.45% saline slowly
Avoid rapid correction (>10 mmol/L/day)
Monitor sodium daily until stable
red_flags: Confusion worsening to seizures or coma
prognosis_disposition: Excellent with gradual correction
Risk of severe neurologic complications if rapid changes

title: Severe Hypernatremia

notes: Risk of brain shrinkage, intracerebral hemorrhage, and death

diagnosis: Clinical features consistent with dehydration and neurological symptoms

details: Use 5% dextrose or hypotonic saline (0.45% NaCl) IV fluids
Aim to lower Na+ by no more than 10-12 mmol/L per 24 hours

management_emergency: Treat underlying cause (e.g., diabetes insipidus, dehydration)
Monitor sodium levels 4-6 hourly
prognosis_disposition: Good if corrected slowly and carefully
Rapid correction risks cerebral edema and death

title: Mild to Moderate Hypocalcaemia

notes: Risk of progression to severe hypocalcemia if untreated

signs: Chvostek's sign (facial twitching) may be positive
Mild muscle irritability (rare in mild cases)
diagnosis: Confirmed serum calcium between 1.9 and 2.1 mmol/L
Identify underlying cause (e.g., vitamin D deficiency, post-thyroidectomy)
management_non_emergency: Oral calcium supplementation (e.g., calcium carbonate or calcium citrate)
Vitamin D supplementation if deficient
Correct associated magnesium deficiency
Monitor calcium every 24-48 hours until stable
prognosis_disposition: Excellent with oral replacement and monitoring
Risk of life-threatening symptoms if untreated

title: Severe Hypocalcemia

notes: Risk of tetany, seizures, and cardiac arrhythmias

signs: Chvostek's sign (facial twitch with tapping facial nerve)
Trousseau's sign (carpopedal spasm with BP cuff inflation)
investigations: PTH level if underlying cause uncertain
diagnosis: Confirmed severe hypocalcemia with or without symptoms
management_emergency: IV calcium gluconate 10% 10-20 mL diluted in 50-100 mL 5% dextrose over 10 minutes
Continuous infusion if necessary
Correct associated magnesium deficiency
Treat underlying cause (e.g., hypoparathyroidism, vitamin D deficiency)
prognosis_disposition: Excellent with early IV calcium replacement
Risk of cardiac arrest if untreated

title: Mild to Moderate Hypokalaemia

notes: Risk of arrhythmias if not corrected

signs: Reduced muscle strength if potassium <3.0 mmol/L
investigations: ECG (may be normal or show mild ST depression or U waves)
management_non_emergency: Oral potassium replacement (e.g., Sando-K or potassium chloride tablets)
Correct associated magnesium deficiency
Review and adjust diuretics or other causative medications
Dietary potassium increase (e.g., bananas, orange juice)
Monitor serum potassium within 24-48 hours
prognosis_disposition: Good with oral supplementation and monitoring
Risk of severe hypokalemia if not treated

title: Severe Hypokalemia

notes: Risk of life-threatening arrhythmias and muscle weakness

signs: Cardiac arrhythmias (may cause palpitations or collapse)
investigations: ECG: flattened T waves, U waves, ST depression, prolonged QT
U&E to assess magnesium, renal function

details: IV potassium chloride infusion (e.g., 20-40 mmol KCl in 1L 0.9% saline over 4-6 hours)

management_emergency: Correct associated magnesium deficiency
Stop potassium-losing drugs (e.g., diuretics)
Treat underlying cause (e.g., diarrhea, vomiting, diuretics)
red_flags: Respiratory muscle weakness (leading to respiratory failure)
prognosis_disposition: Good with early recognition and careful potassium replacement
Mortality high if severe arrhythmia or delayed treatment

title: Mild to Moderate Hyponatraemia

notes: Risk of cerebral edema if sodium falls rapidly

signs: Mild neurological signs if sodium closer to 125 mmol/L (e.g., confusion)
investigations: Thyroid and cortisol tests if necessary
diagnosis: Differentiate between hypovolemic, euvolemic, and hypervolemic causes
management_non_emergency: Treat underlying cause (e.g., fluid restriction for SIADH, volume replacement if hypovolemic)
Fluid restriction (if SIADH): typically 800-1000 mL/day
Oral salt supplementation in some cases
Slow correction to avoid osmotic demyelination (<8 mmol/L/24 hours)
Monitor sodium daily
prognosis_disposition: Excellent with gradual correction
Poor outcome if overcorrected rapidly (osmotic demyelination)

title: Severe Hyponatremia

notes: Risk of cerebral edema and seizures

signs: Signs of volume status (hypovolemia, euvolemia, hypervolemia)
investigations: U&E, thyroid function, cortisol (to assess causes)

details: Hypertonic saline (3% NaCl) cautiously: 100 mL over 10 min, repeat if needed
Aim to raise Na+ by 4-6 mmol/L in first 6 hours

management_emergency: Treat underlying cause (e.g., SIADH, fluid overload, adrenal insufficiency)
Avoid rapid correction (>8 mmol/L/24h) to prevent osmotic demyelination syndrome
red_flags: Osmotic demyelination syndrome from overly rapid correction
prognosis_disposition: Good with controlled correction
Poor outcomes if seizures, brain herniation, or demyelination occur

title: Acute Severe Anemia

definition.criteria: Sudden significant drop in hemoglobin (Hb <70 g/L or symptomatic)
notes: Risk of hypoxia, heart failure, and death

signs: Signs of heart failure (raised JVP, pulmonary edema)
investigations: Investigations to find cause (e.g., GI bleed, hemolysis)
diagnosis: Clinical urgency determined by severity and signs of hypoxia
management_emergency: Oxygen therapy
Blood transfusion (if Hb <70 g/L or symptomatic)
Monitor vitals and cardiac status
Treat underlying cause (e.g., GI bleed, hemolysis, bone marrow failure)
prognosis_disposition: Good with prompt transfusion and stabilization
Prognosis depends on underlying cause

title: Severe Hypoglycemia

definition.criteria: Blood glucose <2.5 mmol/L (Oxford EM Handbook) or <3.0 mmol/L in diabetics
notes: Immediate risk of coma, seizures, and death

signs: Seizures or focal neurological signs (in severe cases)
investigations: Consider insulin level, C-peptide if insulin overdose suspected
diagnosis: Confirmed low blood glucose + clinical symptoms

management_emergency.step: If conscious and able to swallow:
details: Give 15-20g quick-acting carbohydrate (e.g., glucose tablets, sugary drink)

management_emergency.step: If unconscious or unable to swallow:
details: OR IM glucagon 1 mg if no IV access

management_emergency: Recheck glucose after 10-15 min and repeat if necessary
Treat underlying cause (e.g., missed meal, insulin overdose, sepsis)
red_flags: Prolonged hypoglycemia causing irreversible brain damage
prognosis_disposition: Excellent if treated early
Risk of recurrence if underlying cause not corrected

title: Severe Metabolic Acidosis

definition.criteria: Arterial or venous blood pH <7.2 with low bicarbonate
definition.cause: Increased acid production or loss of bicarbonate

signs: Signs of underlying cause (e.g., sepsis, DKA, renal failure)
diagnosis: Identify cause (high anion gap vs normal anion gap)
management_emergency: Treat underlying cause (e.g., fluids and insulin for DKA, antibiotics for sepsis)
IV bicarbonate only if pH <6.9 or life-threatening hyperkalemia
Oxygen therapy if hypoxic
Dialysis if severe renal failure or refractory acidosis
prognosis_disposition: Good with early identification and treatment of cause
Poor if cause untreated or in multi-organ failure

title: Severe Metabolic Alkalosis

definition.criteria: Arterial blood pH >7.6 with elevated bicarbonate
definition.cause: Loss of hydrogen ions or gain of bicarbonate

management_emergency: Correct underlying cause
IV 0.9% saline to correct volume depletion (chloride-responsive alkalosis)
Potassium replacement if needed
Acetazolamide may help increase bicarbonate excretion if saline-resistant
Dialysis in severe or refractory cases
prognosis_disposition: Good if underlying cause corrected
Risk of life-threatening arrhythmias if untreated

title: Severe Thrombocytopenia

notes: Risk of spontaneous bleeding, including intracranial hemorrhage

signs: Signs of anemia if significant blood loss
Signs of underlying cause (e.g., splenomegaly in hematologic disorders)
investigations: Full blood count (isolated low platelet count)
Blood film (to exclude pseudothrombocytopenia or malignancy)
Bone marrow biopsy if cause unclear
diagnosis: Platelet count <30 x 10^9/L with or without bleeding symptoms
management_emergency: Urgent hematology consultation
Platelet transfusion if active bleeding or very low count (<10 x 10^9/L even without bleeding)
Treat underlying cause (e.g., stop offending drugs, treat infection)
IV immunoglobulin (IVIG) or steroids if immune-mediated (e.g., ITP)
prognosis_disposition: Good if underlying cause is reversible and managed promptly
Poor prognosis if associated with bone marrow failure or advanced malignancy
